displaytitle: Tile in kashi gari style, with Koranic inscription
medium: Ceramic with underglaze painting and clear glaze
creditline: Museum purchase, Carl Otto von Kienbusch Jr. Memorial Collection
inscribed:
The inscriptions on this tile are taken from aya 14, sura 23 (surat al-mu'minin) from the Qur'an.  These translations are by Maryam Ekhtiar, Senior Research Associate, and Abdulla Ghouchani, Senior Fellow, both of the Department of Islamic Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art:

Large inscription, from the right: La ilaha illa allah (there is no God but Allah), Muhammad Rasulallah (Muhammad is his messenger) - salallah alayhi wa ila wa salam (may the God's prayer be upon him). 

Small inscription at bottom right: anhum (from them). 

In the medallions: fa-tabarak allah al-ihsan al-Khaliqin--  w'al-hamdulillah Rab al-Alamin (So blessed be to Allah, the best of the creators; and all praise is due to Allah, the of the worlds).

To the upper right of the left medallion: jal jalalahu (reference to the glory of God).

The Shikasteh script derived from both the Ta'liq and Nasta'liq scripts. It is characterized by an exaggerated density in the superstructure letters. Inscribed tiles of this type were made for centuries in the Multan region of Pakistan, in the south central Punjab, near the Chenab River. Although this tile is nineteenth-century in date, it probably replaced an earlier tile of similar nature. It may be compared to the tiles on the façade of the Eid Gah Mosque in Multan, built in 1735 by Nawab Samad Khan, the governor of Multan (see attachment).
